module.title: grunn
grunn
module.p: grunn number, group is a masculine generic quantity noun. Dictionaries list the genitive singular grunna and the plural grunnan.
In terms of the stuff being quantified, grunn generally works like other generic quantity nouns, apart from the fact that it can only be followed by a plural count noun –

ul.li:
When the stuff being quantified is new information, it is usually expressed as a noun modifier/specifier of grunn eg.
Tha grunn chon aig Màiri. Mary has some dogs.
td. 54

When the stuff being quantified is already known, it is usually introduced by the partitive preposition de of governing a specified (ie. ‘definite’) noun eg.
Cheannaich Màiri grunn de mo choin. Mary bought some of my dogs.
td.

When the stuff being quantified is already known, and has just been referred to, or can be inferred, grunn can occur on its own eg.
Tha grunn aig Màiri. Mary has some.
td. 55

Alternatively, grunn can be followed by one of the de prepositional pronouns eg.
Tha grunn dhiubh aig Màiri. Mary has some of them.
td.

module.p:
However, there is some variation in usage to be found here.
td. 44

lix.gd: Ann an dà bhliadhna dheug sgrìobh e fichead leabhar ’s a h-aon ’s dh’ fhàg e grunn mór phàipearan a chùl air a sin.
lix.tr: In 12 years he [Kierkegaard] wrote 21 books and he left a large quantity of papers besides.
